The repo is accessible and writeable anywhere, so anyone can propose changes.
The authors of these changes are referred to as contributors.

Anyone can be a contributor, but established members are what are called committers.
They have a review authority on any proposed changes.
A committer is responsible for evaluating the pull request.
The pull command copies down their change, and then they have a chance to review it.
If they agree with the changes, it's merged back into the main code.
Committers enforce code standards and usually require test code to demonstrate the code works as promised.
Becoming a committer requires you have a proven track record and other committers who are willing to vouch for the quality of your work.
It's worth mentioning here that there's no requirement that an open source project be a certain size.
